data.title: OSX: german keyboard shortcut not recognized
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider 58ab5ecdd9e54643e3ae9ae188021844329c0854
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra

Since recently (sometimes after christmas, haven't done much coding this week), the shortcut to split the editor views doesn't work anymore. By default it is assigned to `cmd+\` and the tooltip correctly maps it to `⌘+#`. But it doesn't split the editor anymore. The devtools don't print any error.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open vscode
2. press `⌘+#` on a german keyboard layout
3. nothing happens

data.title: Feature request: highlight trailing whitespace

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm currently using Trailing Spaces (`shardulm94.trailing-spaces`) for highlighting trailing spaces in my code, but this seems common enough to be a built-in feature.

Ideally the trailing whitespace would highlight in red so it's easy to see, like the extension, but another solution could be adding another value to `editor.renderWhitespace`, like `trailing` or something.

data.title: Command history missing for Bash Integrated Terminal on Windows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:49:23.350Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the user settings, set "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\sysnative\\bash.exe"
2. Restart VS Code
3. Toggle integrated terminal
4. Type a command in the integrated terminal
5. Unlike cmd (or Powershell), command history is not available (whereas it is outside of VS Code)

data.title: Isidorn/debug editor console
Possibility of single key build command?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 8 (64 bit)

**Query:**
I need this badly for working in typescript. I need to pause working, build with ctrl and space key in one hand and B in another, Again mouse click on browser, click refresh to load new JS. Therefore, a single build command would definitely help to reduce this task.
Visual studio provides a simple build key (F6), can we provide the same?

In my opinion, build is a continuous and one of the most vital parts of source code IDE. Therefore, thinking of such solution. I have also checked keyboard shortcut reference and confirm that it is not yet booked.

data.title: Improve xterm.js performance
data.body:
There are a few improvements needed in xterm.js to improve terminal performance

- [x] Use circular list to manage buffer **PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/422**
  - Also fixes scrollback issue https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/361
- [x] ~~Proposal: revamp the refresh method for better rendering performance~~ https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/150 (no longer needed with other changes)
- [x] ~~Performance of refresh is still subpar https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/134~~ (no longer an issue)
- [x] Viewport.refresh seems to be triggered on every line of input https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/290 (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/438**)
- [x] Refresh limit system makes performance bad on Windows https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/280 (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/438**)
- [x] Commands that fill a non-full buffer lock up the terminal for a couple of seconds https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/444 (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/445**)
- [x] Reconsider XON/XOFF PR to keep slave in sync with terminal https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/425 (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/447**)
- [x] Too much time is spent in getBoundingClientRect (no issue) (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/440**)
- [x] ~~Investigate reuse of DOM nodes to reduce browser garbage collection https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/449 (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/450**)~~ Deferred until results are proven or the model is needed for something else
- [x] :muscle: Optimize parser https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/459 (**PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/462**)

data.title: Multi cursor deselects when typing brackets in multiple positions on same line
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
```
Version 1.8.1
Commit ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281
Date 2016-12-19T14:41:20.664Z
Shell 1.4.6
Renderer 53.0.2785.143
Node 6.5.0
```
- OS Version:
`Ubuntu 16.04  Kernel: 4.4.0-47-generic`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file - I have reproduced with `.less`, `.js` and `.html`
2. Select somewhere
3. Hold `alt` and select somewhere else further along the same line
4. Open and close a pair of brackets
5. Notice that the second pair (and all other subsequent pairs) of brackets did not close and the cursor is now only selecting the left-most place on the line.

The issue does *not* occur when typing only a closing bracket (unless that closing bracket is immediately after an opening one)

I've tried this with extensions both enabled and disabled - the issue is present in both situations

There are no errors in the dev tools console

data.title: improve indentation rules
data.body:
# Indentation

## Intro
[Indent Style](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indent_style) is a convention to convey the structure of source code to human readers in programming languages. It's not a requirement in most programming languages but usually language authors adopt a style for their sample code and encourage users to use that. In some particular programming languages, Python for example, indentations are even meaningful to compilers/interpreters, wrong indentations may lead to compiling or runtime errors. 

VS Code helps users to write correct indentations with ease. To make this happen, we followed [TextMate](https://manual.macromates.com/en/appendix)'s style and implemented three regexp patterns you can set to tell VS Code when to increase or decrease indentations.

* `increaseIndentPattern`
* `decreaseIndentPattern`
* `indentNextLinePattern` 
* `unIndentedLinePattern`

However, these regexp patterns only decide whether we should modify the indentaion of a line if it matches one pattern, they don't tell us when is a good time to apply the modification. There are two ways to implement this feature, an active one and a passive one.

* **Active**: Whenever the model changes(user input, code format, etc), run indentaion regex rules against current line.
* **Passive**: Whenever users press `enter` key, run indentaion regex rules against current line.

## Active or Passive
The active way looks really good as the indentation can be adjusted immediately when the content of current line matches the indentation rule. Take Ruby `def/end` block as an example:

![ruby-indentation](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/876920/20914835/fa4d0b96-bb36-11e6-9997-65292ef52774.gif)

Ruby programmers or anyone running into similar situation may only be 100% satisfied if we adjust the indentation correctly once they press `d` as part of the closing keyword `end`. But the catch is users might keep typing after we modify the indentation, the content of current line may not match any regex rule any more, should we keep an eye on that and undo previous indentation change? To make things worse, if any indentation regex rule contains `$`, which matches the ending position of a line, how can we tell whether users **finish typing in current line** or not?

Taking above into consideration, passive way might be more reasonable. When a user press `enter`, he or she is sure that the content in current line is satisfactory for the moment and wants to work on following lines. We can calcualte the final indentation for current line and do the updates if it is different from the existing one. Besides, we can calculate the potential *correct* indentation level for the following line.

In VS Code we chose the passive way.

## Are we in good shape now?
We implemented the logic described above (there are several other components that contribute to the indentation, we'll discuss that later) but it's not precisely as expected. Currently we got somewhat wrong with the semantics of `decreaseIndentPattern` and there might be other cases that might be related or similar:

* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1620
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2023
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/2272
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4039
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7671
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10307
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11322
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11909
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15301
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/15598
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17281
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/17639

## TODO
- [x] enrich support for `decreaseIndentPattern`
- [x] auto indent selection
- [x] move lines should honor indentation

data.title: Add line number text property
data.body: Currently there is no way to change the line number text in vscode. the reason I am asking for this is because I would like to create a relative line number extension. This is helpful for vim users, who would like to know the number of lines from current selected.

data.title: The whole file name is used when dealing with filename associations
data.body:
Fixes #17864

I've changed the behavior of the filename associations so they use the whole filename (including the extension(s)) instead of using just the name, which was causing the effects explained in #17864 and [vscode-icons #557](https://github.com/robertohuertasm/vscode-icons/issues/557).

data.title: Filename associations are not working as expected
data.body:
- VSCode Version: version 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create an icon theme.
2. Create a filename that has no extension. e.g. license
3. Create a file called `license` and it will work as expected
4. Create a file called `license.ts` and instead of the expected `ts` icon, you will see the `license` icon.

It seems that filename associations are created by taking the extension of the file as a separated style, thus providing side-effects with `filenames` without extension.

In my opinion, filenames shouldn't have to take into account the extension as a separate css class. The whole file name should be css parsed and used as a class name instead. This would avoid the described issue.

See [vscode-icons #557](https://github.com/robertohuertasm/vscode-icons/issues/557)

data.title: Adds support for moving the tab close button to the left
data.body:
I've added support for moving the tab close button to the left of the tab. I've implemented it in the simplest way possible, by adding a new setting called `tabCloseButtonOnLeft`. But I'm open to opinions regarding the possibility to refactor the `showTabCloseButton` and `tabCloseButtonOnLeft` into a single setting specifying if it's hidden or on which side should it be displayed.

Fixes #15833

data.title: Please add the option to remove the blobs on the right hand side scrollbar
data.body:
VSCode Version: 1.9.0-insider OS Version: OSX El Capitan 10.11.4 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Open a file when the editor is open 2. Click on some text that also appears in another part of the file In the below example, I have clicked on a `
    ` tag. ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10364894/21504250/1baeeb90-cc55-11e6-93c0-c3c2e266ad0a.png) There are two other parts of the file where this text occurs; the closing `
` tag, and a completely unrelated word, `default`, which just happens to also contain the text `ul`. It's not useful for this to be highlighted. In fact, it's confusing and distracting. Please add the option to toggle the appearance of these blobs.

data.body:

- Extensions installed:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open up a .php file
2. Within a php file (in my case a functions file for Wordpress) when I go to create a variable, eg: `$sm_content`, it turns it into `<1sm_content></1sm_content>` upon hitting tab. Hitting space before hitting tab does not cause this, only when the cursor is right up against the variable name.
3. Restarted VSC, still same results.
